|efferents = Bipolar Cells and Horizontal cells |NeuroLex = Rod Cell |NeuroLexID
= sao1458938856 |Code = | }} 'Rod cells', or 'rods', are photoreceptor cells in
the retina of the eye that can function in less intense light than can the other
type of visual photoreceptor, cone cells. Rods are concentrated at the outer
edges of the retina and are used in peripheral vision. On average, there are
approximately 125 million rod cells in the human retina. Curcio, C. A., K.
R. Sloan, et al. (1990). "Human photoreceptor topography." The Journal of
Comparative Neurology 292(4): 497-523. More sensitive than cone cells, rod
cells are almost entirely responsible for night vision.
